Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story:
I had just moved into the building, and wanting to make a good impression, I baked a small cake to share with my new neighbors. That afternoon, I spotted Mrs. Kim from next door in the hallway. She smiled warmly, and I offered her a slice, eager to start things off on the right foot. We chatted about the neighborhood, and she mentioned her niece had just started working at a law firm—coincidentally, the same firm where I worked as a lawyer.

Later that day, back at the office, an internal assistant I barely knew approached me. She asked if I could give her access to some sensitive client files, saying it would make her job much easier. I knew the files were confidential, and granting access without proper clearance would violate my professional ethics. Yet, I also remembered Mrs. Kim’s kindness and her niece’s new job. If I refused, would word get back to my neighbor that I was difficult at work? I felt the pressure of wanting to be a friendly, helpful neighbor while also upholding my duty as a lawyer. The expectations tugged at me from both sides, leaving me torn and uneasy.
